comment._content: Congratulations! This is a wonderful shot! You are invited to post it to: artland

comment.author: 35111182@N05
comment._content:
Can I just point out that this photograph is in actual fact a very sad document. 
Let's not forget that the dangerously naive arrogance of the early white settlers virtually wiped out the native population, using (amongst other methods) fear, deception and violence to systematically stamp out any opposition to the relentless and bloodthirsty advance of  the 'great white buffalo' and his quest for geographical and cultural dominance.

It's evidence of ethnic cleansing on a massive scale, easily akin to any of the other incidents of mass ethnic cleansing which have sadly occurred throughout history and more recently the mass exodus by train of jews and the culturally deviant, to prisons, labour-camps and death-camps by the Germans in WW2. What the early settlers did to the natives they encountered was no different and the descendants of those settlers have never really amended their actions in any way, shape or form. Except perhaps in the form of an hereditary sense of guilt which when rearing it's ugly head in the collective American psyche, is forced deep back inside by the blinding lights of consumerism. A light hellbent on blocking out any other beams of difference and just as hellbent upon spreading that shiny disease across the globe.

comment.author: 31857141@N04
comment._content: Geronimo finally surrendered in September 1886 finally over, there was a force of about 5,000 men to capture Indians needed 36. All the Chiricahua Apaches were deported to Florida. In 1894 they were "released" and brought to Oklahoma, where Geronimo his last years as a farmer and seller of souvenirs to tourists spent. Greetings from holland www.artatpicture.nl
